summary: Great job for people looking to work in health
pros: Very good atmosphere and the staff are friendly. There�s a lot of benefits and a lot of room for growth within the company or within your health careers in general.

pros: The team at MSG is simply amazing. Many places say "Well, at least we're not curing cancer." But here you really are. If you want to be a part of a mission driven team - and work in a TRUE Agile environment - then this is the best of all worlds. If you want to do UX with an exceptional team - here is your chance to.
cons: That said - a BIG con is that MSK is a research facility. Many projects are on the do we have the funding for it track - and that is year by year. So, you might start out on a great project - only to have it retired before you complete it.

pros:
- Always looking to improve as an institution
- Plenty of opportunity for career growth
- Consistently demonstrates the impact of your work
cons: - Tend to offer at the lower end of the expected salary range but it is still competitive for the industry.

pros: Meaningful mission, nice people to work with.
cons: Leadership pivots decisions every few months. Resources thin.

summary: A lot of potential to be a dream job.
pros: Incredible learning opportunities, options to conduct research and/or pursue PhD/DSW alongside workload with education reimbursement, fulfilling work, ability to submit abstract and present at annual AOSW conference (with reimbursement for flight, hotel, etc), strong mentorship to improve writing and presentation skills, CEUs provided through department, weekly to biweekly supervision provided, reimbursement provided for higher licensure
cons: Large caseloads (between 30-60 inpatient patients at a time for my services), strong hierarchal structure, not able to change managers if not a good fit without leaving your position, social work's required management of the Philanthropy program, larger focus on outpatient social work/patient needs instead of inpatient needs, few ways to offer direct feedback to department unless it's through direct supervisor, difficulty participating in career opportunities due to high caseload demands, difficulty navigating need for increase in compensation (often only comes through promotion or annual quality of life increase from MSK), limited promotion track, work/life balance

pros: They have healthcare, but it would probably be sad if a hospital/institute didn't give decent healthcare to employees.
cons: The work to pay ratio is quite poor, especially compared to the pharma industry

pros: Great benefits, great pay, camaraderie amongst coworkers, opportunity for career development
cons: Just like any job in healthcare, there is a great need for patient care and sometimes we are understaffed

pros: Flexible, overall great company vision, great benefits
cons: N/a, no cons from me personally.

pros: I have been at MSK for 4 year and I love it. I'm constantly being challenged and management cares about our career growth and helps us along the way to get there, Great benefits, salary and culture

summary: MSK does not value their hourly employees
pros: Benefits are very good, employer retirement contributions hiring than standard
cons:
Internal hiring process unfair, making it difficult to move to another position to make more money. Ability for Care Coorindators and Office coordinators to increase their salary for experience was taken away, some even had their salary decreased due to "restructuring" 
Training not optimal, creating a revolving door for the Cooridinator position.

summary: Pay does not match how much work we are given
pros: Friendly co-workers and good benefits.
cons: Extremely stressful, fast-paced environment and you don't feel fulfilled as you are paid very little for how much work you are doing.

summary: Not much here for experienced PMs
pros:
- Strong name recognition in Healthcare, ability to work at world leading cancer org
- Mostly remote, only need to be onsite few days a month
- Great WLB, never signed off later than 5pm, unofficial tech summer Fridays (If your manager respects it)
cons:
If you are an experienced PM who wants to break into Healthcare at a top institution, you will certainly get that here, but you overall will be extremely frustrated to the point of wanting to check out.

- Insanely bureaucratic PM org (Safe agile, need I saw more?)
- Lots of PM leaders with 0 understanding of what a PM is
- Emphasis on project management over product management
- 2 boss structure for every employee (Work boss and HR manager)
- Limited room for growth
- Mandatory onsite days are often wastes of time
- POs/Teams will shift at random to new projects with little onboarding or training, left to figure it out for yourself
- Some managers foster culture with no room for feedback
- Underskilled and understaffed tech teams

pros: Nurses never have to use their brains

pros: Self scheduling is implemented and theres resources on the unit

summary: 50/50- You'll either like working here or not.
pros:
1. Everyone is so welcoming! 
2. Pay is great, so negotiate well. 
3. Depending on who you'll report to, some Manager(s), Principal Investigator(s), and/or Core Head(s) are very understanding and fun and will support you.
cons:
1. You'll work for two Manager(s), Principal Investigator(s) and/or Core Head(s) who will require different things.
 
2. Not fully transparent- When I applied, the job posting stated it was a hybrid position. During my interview, all interviewers told me I could work from home any two days of my choosing. Once I got hired, I was told I had to wait six months before I could work from home. Once I reached the six-month mark, I was told that it was up to my main manager to decide whether or not I could work from home... my manager denied it. During the whole process, it seemed as if working from home was a definite thing I could do. There was no transparency during the interview. No one told me it was up to my supervisor to decide, and he did not want his admin to work from home (which HR knew since he told them).

Disclaimer: Other admins did work from home! It all depends on the manager/ head of the team, who will approve it, so ask during the interviews!

pros: Great colleagues, supportive co-fellows, opportunities for learning, world-class institution

pros: The pay is competitive and market adjustments are made regularly. The opportunity for promotion using the clinical ladder is a great way to give yourself more opportunities financially and professionally.
cons: Because you first have to take on more tasks before you apply for promotion, there are many months of extra work without extra pay. There are also no Assistant Nursing Managers in the institution becuase they expect nurses who are climbing the clinical ladder to take on the typical Assistant Nurse Manager roles.

cons: High workload and demanding deadlines.

summary: Was better in the outpatient offices

cons: The outpatient facilities pre covid were normal patient to nurse ratio, post COVID our ratio is much more and the patient are coming to the outpatient facility much sicker.
